text: - Hi, I'm Michael Soo,
I build migration services here at AWS,

and I wanna share some
information with you
about the tools that we offer customers

to migrate their data
warehouses into the cloud.
A data warehouse is really just a database
that's been optimized for analytics,

and that means managing big
data to compute business metrics

or to feed advanced analytics,
like machine learning models.

So, Amazon Redshift is our
managed data warehouse offering.
With Amazon Redshift,

you let AWS automate all the
day-to-day administration tasks
for your data warehouse,

and it lets you leverage the
compute and storage resources
that we can provide at cloud scale.

So, tens of thousands of
customers use Amazon Redshift

to gain new insights from
their data every day.
And you can use Redshift
to query, literally, exabytes of data

across your data warehouse,
your operational data stores,
and your data lake using standard SQL.
You can integrate other AWS services
such as Amazon EMR, Amazon Athena,

Amazon SageMaker, AWS
Glue, AWS Lake Formation,
and Amazon Kinesis

to utilize all the
capabilities that we provide
in the AWS Cloud.

So, how can you migrate
into Amazon Redshift?

Well, if you've been
operating your data warehouse
on premises,

it can be a significant
investment to migrate into AWS.

For example, you may be
using a proprietary engine
that offers a feature set

that's very different
from Amazon Redshift,

and that would mean
lots of data conversion,

code refactoring, and
maybe even re-architecture

of your data ingestion and
consumption applications.
But my team has been working very hard
for the last few years

to automate many aspects
of this migration process,
so we've really listened to our customers

and delivered dozens of
features in our tools:
the AWS Schema Conversion Tool, or SCT,

the AWS database migration
service, we call it DMS,

and Amazon Redshift to
accelerate your migrations.

So, what I'd like to do is maybe
share a couple of examples.

Your workload may rely on
non-standard, proprietary features

that aren't directly
supported by Amazon Redshift.

So, for example, you
could be using set tables.

And set tables are very
similar to primary keys,

except that they guarantee what
we call full row uniqueness.
And there are some subtle differences,

but it's essentially as if all
the attributes in the table
were part of the primary key.

So if you have applications
that depend on set semantics,

you need a way to emulate
that same behavior
in Amazon Redshift.

Well, now, we're happy to
provide an ability to use AW SET
to automatically convert your SQL code.
SET will analyze your SQL
and inject code into your SQL stream
that will check for duplicates
before they're inserted into the database.
And if you're building a new application
that uses set tables,
we've also published a how-to blog
that describes the transformation

so that you can replicate
the process yourself.
So, AWS DMS,
or just DMS,
is our managed database migration service.

You can use DMS to replicate
data into Amazon Redshift.
And we've recently enhanced DMS
with parallel-load capabilities

that are optimized
specifically for Redshift.

So, in the traditional
process, you have a pipeline,
and each step in that pipeline was serial,

so you would first extract
data, upload that data to S3,

and then have that data
copied into Amazon Redshift.

Well, DMS now supports what
we call parallel full load,
and with parallel full load,
the ingestion process into Amazon Redshift
runs at the parallel degree you choose.

You control how many
parallel sessions to use
with a DMS task setting,
and you can dial it up or dial it down
to meet your particular use case.

Finally, let me share an
enhancement to Amazon Redshift

that we built to make it easier
to migrate your ETL streams.

Many customers depend on
database scripting to run ETL,
and in a large warehouse,

you may have pipelines with
tens of thousands of scripts

that were written in
your particular vendor's
proprietary language.
So to help with those migrations,
we created a tool called RSQL.
RSQL is a purpose-built scripting tool
optimized for Amazon Redshift.

With RSQL, you can execute
SQL statements to build,
cleanse, and transform your data.
RSQL also includes control logic,
so you can monitor and detect

when your pipeline is
executing correctly or not
and then take appropriate action.
So, these are just a few

of the dozens of enhancements
we've made recently
to enable migrations into Amazon Redshift.

For more details, you can
visit the AWS Blog's website.

See the description for
links to relevant posts.

Otherwise, I hope you found
this information useful,
and happy migrating.
(upbeat music)
